sectionTitle: Project Cash Flows: A First Look

columns.text: In this problem, we are going to define terms used in the chapter.
**a.** Cash flow refers to the intake and outgoings of cash in a certain company or a project. This provides a good image of whether the company or project is currently making or losing money.

The **incremental cashflow** refers to the cashflow of a company relative to the project. It determines how the project can impact the cashflow of the company by determining the cashflow of the company without the project and comparing it to the cashflow of the company with the project. 

Just like in the normal cashflow, a positive value is good while a negative value generally means that the project is not good for the company and thus should not be continued or accepted.

**b.** The stand alone principle uses only the incremental cashflow as basis on whether or not a certain project is good for the company. This means that it only considers the cashflow of the project and how it affects the cashflow of the company. This may not always be the best method since there may be other factors that can affect the incremental cashflow making the stand alone principle an inaccurate measure of success for a project.
**10.1a** In this part of the question, we are asked to determine the appropriate incremental cash flows that should be considered while evaluating projects.Â

The cash flows attributable to the project being examined, net of any other projects being evaluated at the same time, are the relevant incremental cash flows for project evaluation. **This comprises cash flows related solely to the project under consideration**, as well as cash flows attributable to both the project under consideration and any other projects under consideration at the same time. A cash flow model, such as the discounted cash flow (DCF) model, can be used to estimate the incremental cash flows for a particular project.
**10.1b** In this question, we are asked to define the stand alone principle.

The **stand-alone principle** is a financial philosophy that asserts that a company should be able to survive without outside funding. This notion is vital for businesses because it maintains their independence and prevents them from being dependent on the activities of outside investors or financial institutions. Investors benefit from the stand-alone concept because **it allows them to invest in firms without having to worry about their financial viability in the future.** This is because a company that adheres to the stand-alone concept can create its own revenue and function without requiring outside funding.
